Graphical abstract This study illustrates the fundamentals of the photoelectrochemical water splitting process. The impact of metal chalcogenides in improving visible light absorption and photoelectrochemical performance is also discussed. Photoelectrochemical water splitting (PEC-WS) is a promising technique for transforming solar energy into storable and environmentally friendly chemical energy. Designing semiconductor photoelectrodes with high light absorption capability, rapid e−/h+ separation and transfer, and sufficient chemical stability is vital for developing an efficient PEC-WS system. Metal chalcogenides (MCs) have emerged as promising candidates for light absorbers because of their unique electrical and optical characteristics. In this review, we present recent developments in hydrogen generation via PEC-WS using MC-based photoelectrodes. First, we present a simple illustration of PEC-WS fundamentals. Second, the current performance of various metal (mono-, di-, and tri-) chalcogenide/semiconductor photoelectrodes in PEC-WS is summarized. Then, the charge transfer mechanism at the MC/semiconductor interface and the PEC-WS mechanism is thoroughly explained. Finally, we discuss future research perspectives toward developing efficient and stable MC/semiconductor photoelectrodes. Keywords Photoelectrochemical water splitting Metal chalcogenides Photoelectrode Energy conversion 1 Introduction The most plentiful renewable energy source is sunlight (∼1.2 × 1014 kJ arrives at the Earth’s surface per second) [1]. The conversion of sunlight into heat, electricity, or fuel is a significant route for using renewable energy [2]. The required global hydrogen production for the industry is approximately 0.1 gigatons, which is essentially consumed in NH3 production (54%), chemical generation (35%), electronics (6%), metal refining/processing (3%), and food manufactures (2%) [3]. The global demand for hydrogen as fuel increases because of the increased domestic consumption of hydrogen and its use in the transportation fuel industry. This increased demand requires improvement in hydrogen production processes, storage, and transport. Although significant progress has been achieved in hydrogen storage and transportation, the use of hydrogen energy is hindered by the lack of cost-effective and practical generation techniques [4]. Hydrogen can be produced using various techniques categorized into two groups based on the raw materials utilized. The first category includes technologies that utilize fossil fuels, such as hydrocarbon reforming and hydrocarbon pyrolysis. The second category includes the approaches that use renewable sources such as biomass and water [5,6]. The detailed pathways for H2 generation are shown in Fig. 1 . Sustainable hydrogen generation from water splitting (WS) has attracted significant interest owing to its high energy density and possibility for use without emitting carbon [7,8]. The photoelectrochemical WS (PEC-WS) cell can convert H2O and sunlight directly into H2 and O2. The produced H2 from PEC-WS could mitigate the problem of global warming by reducing dependency on fossil fuels [9–14]. Oxygen is also an essential treatment for patients in all healthcare systems [15]. Recently, the global need for oxygen has surged due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The reasons for lowering the solar conversion efficiency are (1) limited light absorption of photocatalysts, (2) inefficient use of photogenerated charges leads to rapid recombination, and (3) poor surface redox reactions [16]. As a result, researchers have investigated a variety of semiconductors and developed novel approaches to overcome these problems. Among the aforementioned causes, the relaxation of hot electrons through electron-photon scattering, and posterior photon dissipation is the main problem [17]. The use of semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) can overcome this problem through the multiple exciton generation (MEG) process, which involves the cooling of excitons by generating more e−/h+. Thus, the external quantum efficiency (the number of generated electron-hole pairs as a function of the number of absorbed photons) is improved by more than 100% for wavelengths that can generate excitons with sufficient energy to undergo the MEG process. Yong Yan et al. constructed a PbS QD PEC cell that drove the H2 generation using Na2S electrolyte, with an external quantum efficiency of more than 100% [18]. Chalcogenides compounds consist of chalcogens (S, Se, Te) as anions and electropositive cations [16]. Metal chalcogenides (MCs) can be divided into three categories according to their chemical composition; metal mono- (MX), di- (MX2), and tri- (MX3) chalcogenides. M refers to the metal element, and X refers to the chalcogen. Each category has unique crystal structures and properties that can broaden its optoelectronic applications [19]. MCs have piqued researchers’ interest because of their exceptional light-harvesting capacity and unique energy levels [20]. Therefore, MCs have been applied in various energy generating and storage applications, including batteries, photovoltaics, catalysis, and artificial photosynthesis devices [21]. MCs have been evaluated as promising photocatalysts compared to oxides owing to their higher light absorption coefficient, preferable energy level alignment, and plenty of active sites [16,22–25]. Additionally, transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) as photoanodes can theoretically attain the best solar to hydrogen efficiency in the optimized PEC system [26]. MCs photoelectrodes have been extensively studied for PEC-WS [27–29]. For example, MoS2 is a promising and low-cost alternative to Pt electrodes for H2 generation from EC- and PEC-WS processes [30]. CdS has attracted considerable attention for PC and PEC-WS under visible light because of its desirable characteristics such as suitable bandgap, appropriate band position, and high H2 generation efficiency [31–33]. However, it suffers from rapid e−/h+ recombination and photo-corrosion. TMCs have various compositions with different lattice features and distinctive electronic structures [34]. Consequently, they have been used in various energy applications [25]. Transition metal di-chalcogenides (TMDCs) are present in three crystal phases: 1 T (AA stacking, tetragonal), 2H (ABAB stacking, hexagonal), and seldom in 3R (ABCABC stacking, rhombohedral), as shown in Fig. 2 . TMDCs materials are auspicious because of their unique optical, physical, and electronic features [35,36]. Recently, several reviews have discussed the optical properties of TMCs and their configurations, as well as their applications in various optoelectronics and photonics [19,37–40]. Other reviews have been focused on hydrogen production from the WS process based on TMCs [4,41–45]. The main goal of this review is to outline the latest progress in hydrogen production via PEC-WS using MC-based photoelectrodes. First, we provide a brief overview of PEC-WS fundamentals. Second, the recent PEC-WS performance of various metal (mono-, di-, and tri-) chalcogenide/semiconductor photoelectrodes is summarized in terms of light absorption ability, e−/h+ separation and transfer, and surface reactions. Then, detailed mechanisms of charge transfer at the MC/semiconductor interface and PEC-WS are explained. Finally, we discuss future research perspectives toward developing efficient and stable MC/semiconductor photoelectrodes in the conclusion. We expect that this review will help researchers to design effective MC-based photoelectrodes for the PEC-WS cell. 2 Fundamentals of photoelectrochemical water splitting PEC solar fuel generation presents a straightforward way of renewable solar to chemical energy conversion compared with traditional photovoltaic technology, which uses standard devices for electrochemical fuel production [13,26]. This is ascribed to the simple design of a PEC system, which comprises at least two electrodes (anode and cathode) and a membrane to separate products. Additionally, one of the electrodes at least should be a semiconductor that can absorb photons energy that is greater than its bandgap. The photopotential formed by e−/h+ separation can undergo electrochemical solar to fuel production [26]. Moreover, a PEC system can be developed in a tandem configuration with n-type photoanode and p-type photocathode semiconductors to improve the system’s photopotential and light absorption ability [47]. Additionally, the PEC-WS technique offers some advantages over photocatalytic WS (PC-WS), such as (1) the self or external bias can mitigate e−/h+ recombination rate and thereby improve their separation and transfer; (2) the easy separation of H2 and O2 through gathering at two different electrodes; (3) the coating of semiconductor thin films on various conductive substrates, that makes it suitable for industrial use in the future; and (4) it does not require stirring; therefore, it consumes low power compared to powder PC-WS systems [48]. In 1972, Fujishima and Honda discovered the PEC-WS, which uses TiO2 and Pt as an n-type photoanode and cathode, respectively, immersed in an electrolyte. TiO2 absorbed photon’s energy and generated sufficient potential to split H2O into H2 and O2 [49]. Many researchers have identified the fundamentals of the PEC-WS process [50–53], and a variety of semiconductor-based photoelectrodes such as metal oxides [54–58], metal chalcogenides [59–63], have been reported. However, the PEC-WS process is still challenging because the electrodes are directly contacted with the electrolyte. Therefore, the stability of electrodes against corrosion needs to be improved. In addition, the configuration of the PEC-WS device is more limited [64]. The most essential requirements for achieving a competitive PEC-WS system are (1) harvesting a large portion of the sunlight; (2) excellent e−/h+ separation and transfer; (3) low overpotential for H2 and O2 evolution reaction; (4) demonstration of high stability; (5) scalable techniques and (6) affordable materials [50]. Photocurrent-voltage (J-V) measurement is essential for evaluating the PEC-WS performance of different photoelectrodes [65]. Although metal oxide semiconductors (TiO2, BiVO4, and Fe2O3) are cheap and stable for electrochemical processes [66–72], they exhibit low efficiency for hydrogen production under the sunlight because of their limited charge transfer mobility and feeble light absorption. Therefore, various strategies have been studied to overcome these issues and boost their PEC performance, for example, (i) morphology and size control, (ii) cocatalysts loading, (iii) doping with metals and non-metals, (iv) heterojunction with narrow bandgap semiconductors [73,74]. 2.1 PEC-WS fundamental processes PEC-WS is an uphill process involving several procedures that must be managed to optimize the device’s efficiency. The fundamental processes involved in PEC-WS are addressed in this section and shown in Fig. 3 (a and b); (1) light absorption and charge photogeneration, (2) charge separation and transfer, and (3) water splitting redox reactions. 2.1.1 Light absorption and charge photogeneration When light penetrates the semiconductor, the electronic structure of the semiconductor interacts with the electromagnetic wave. This interaction leads to the excitation of some electrons from the valance band (VB) to the conduction band (CB) generating holes in the VB [52]. The energy difference among CB and VB of semiconductors is the bandgap. When photon energy exceeds the bandgap of a semiconductor, the excited electrons transfer the excess energy to neighboring atoms in the form of thermal vibration to be stabilized in CB [50]. Various metal oxides semiconductors have been investigated as photoelectrodes due to their good chemical resistance. However, their wide bandgap energy limits their light absorption to the UV field. Therefore, poor PEC-WS efficiency has been established under sunlight [75]. To overcome this problem, some studies have focused on using narrow bandgap semiconductors [76–78]. Combining narrow bandgap and wide bandgap semiconductors has shown a significant improvement for both counterparts in terms of overcoming the disadvantages of both semiconductors in a composite and increasing PEC-WS efficiency [79]. This point will be explained in detail in section 3.1. Fig. 3(c) illustrates the bandgap energy and band edge position of some promising metal oxides, nitrides, and chalcogenides with respect to redox potentials of water. Another technique to improve light-harvesting ability is the deposition of plasmonic metal nanoparticles (NPs) that exhibit localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) [80-82]. LSPR effect is the oscillation of surface electrons in the plasmonic metal NPs with irradiated light. The LSPR-induced PEC-WS efficiency improvements involve: (1) localized electric field enhancement, (2) boosted light absorption, and (3) hot-electron transfer [83]. Various research studies have investigated the utilization of plasmonic metals NPs in the PEC-WS, where the light-harvesting in the visible region was controlled by the type, size, and shape of the metal [84–88]. 2.1.2 Charge separation and transfer In order to properly split water and produce H2 and O2, the photogenerated carriers in the photoelectrode must be separated before reaching the active sites to avoid the recombination process. The recombination occurs when the excited electrons lose their energy and return to the holes in the VB [50]. The main hurdle of charge carriers transfer to the active sites in the photoelectrode is the recombination process because the high recombination degree makes extracting current from charge carriers difficult [50,89,90]. The separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers are influenced by the crystal structure of materials, crystallinity degree, and particle size. The materials with high crystallinity and lower defects demonstrate high photocatalytic activity because the defects act as trapping centers, increasing the recombination rate of charge carriers. The nanomaterials have a short diffusion distance between charge carriers and active sites, reducing recombination likelihood. They also have a high surface-to-volume ratio, which improves the interaction between photogenerated charge and active sites [90]. Additionally, the morphology of the deposited materials, defect features, and electrolyte composition affect the transfer of photogenerated charge [91–94]. For instance, the 1D structure of nanomaterials such as nanotubes can improve charge transfer through the linear transport path [93]. Applying an external potential or generating an internal built-in potential can improve charge carrier separation and prevent recombination. The different ways to create internal potential involve the formation of heterojunctions with different materials, doping of elements, and metal incorporation onto the semiconductor [95]. Some structures generating built-in electric field are (1) p–n homojunction, where a semiconductor substance has two different areas with different characters (i.e., p-type and n-type silicon), (2) p–n heterojunction includes the contact between two different substances with different characters (i.e., n-type WO3 and p-type silicon), (3) Schottky junction, where a semiconductor substance equilibrates with the free electrons energy level of the metal (i.e., nickel metal and n-type silicon), (4) semiconductor-liquid junction (SCLJ), where the semiconductor substance equilibrates with the adsorbed ions on the surface, generating a Helmholtz double layer (i.e., n-type WO3 in a basic electrolyte) [50]. Heterojunction construction between two semiconductors is an effective way to promote charge separation. The heterojunction between two semiconductors can be categorized based on the energy band alignment into three types [96,97]. (1) Straddling-gap heterojunctions (type-I), where photogenerated electrons and holes are migrated from semiconductor A to semiconductor B (Fig. 4 a), resulting in a large accumulation of e−/h+ in semiconductor B and causing severe charge recombination. (2) Staggered-gap heterojunctions (type-II), where photogenerated electrons in semiconductor B are transferred to semiconductor A; meanwhile, the photogenerated holes on semiconductor A are transported to semiconductor B, resulting in efficient charge separation (Fig. 4b). (3) Broken-gap heterojunctions (type-III), where there is no directional transfer of photogenerated charge among semiconductor A and semiconductor B (Fig. 4c). 2.1.3 Water splitting redox reactions The photogenerated charge can be separated by the built-in electric field. In the case of a photoanode, holes are migrated to the surface of the photoelectrode to undergo the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), whereas the electrons are gathered through the back contact to reduce the protons at the counter electrode (Fig. 3a). In the case of a photocathode, the electrons are driven to the surface to carry out the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) (Fig. 3b) [50,98,99]. The reaction of water splitting is a non-spontaneous reaction. It can occur when an external potential is applied between two electrodes (anode and cathode) submerged in an electrolyte to undergo the OER and HER. The complete reaction of H2O splitting requires the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of 237.2 kJ/mol, which corresponds to thermodynamic reversible potential of 1.23 V, which is a theoretical value at ionic concentration, gas pressure, and temperature of 1 molar, 1 atm, and 25 °C, respectively. The potential value varies with electrolyte pH according to the Nernst equation: E RHE = E NHE + 0.059·pH, where E RHE is the potential versus reversible hydrogen electrode, and E NHE is the potential versus normal hydrogen electrode. The two half reactions for the overall H2O splitting to produce H2 and O2 based on the electrolyte pH are explained as follows [50,100]. Under acidic conditions OER: 2 H 2 O − 4 e - → O 2 + 4 H + , (E 0 = 1.23 V vs. NHE at pH = 0) HER: 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 , (E 0 = 0.00 V vs. NHE at pH = 0) Under basic conditions OER: 4 O H - − 4 e - → O 2 + 2 H 2 O , (E 0 = 0.40 V vs. NHE at pH = 14) HER: 2 H 2 O + 2 e - → H 2 + 2 O H - , (E 0 = − 0.83 V vs. NHE at pH = 14) 2.2 Material requirements In all solar conversion systems, the semiconductor material is the most crucial component, which absorbs photon energy and generates excited electrons (e−) and holes (h+). This photogenerated e−/h+ can migrate in opposite directions with the formation of photopotential, which drives the production of fuel such as H2 [26]. The solar-to-hydrogen conversion (STH) efficiency of the PEC-WS system is mainly based on (1) light absorption, (2) e−/h+ photogeneration, and (3) e−/h+ separation and migration [98]. When choosing a semiconductor to utilize as a photoelectrode, there are a few principles to keep in mind; 2.2.1 Potential requirement Under standard conditions, the splitting of one molecule of water to H2 and ½ O2 requires ΔG of 237.2 kJ/mol, which corresponds to ΔE = 1.23 V per electron transported. The combined semiconductors should absorb light radiation with photon energy greater than 1.23 eV and consume this energy to split water. This procedure must produce four h+ per O2 molecule (4 × 1.23 = 4.92 eV) or two e− per H2 molecule (2 × 1.23 = 2.46 eV) [13]. The semiconductor bandgap should be between 1.23 and 2.4 eV to allow the photoelectrode to absorb visible light, which accounts for half of the solar energy spectrum [52]. Additionally, some energy loss such as the overpotential loss at the photoelectrode and ionic conductivity loss in the electrolyte should be considered. As a result, the required potential for water splitting is 1.6–2.0 V [102]. 2.2.2 The band edge structure When choosing appropriate materials, the band edge position and charge carrier diffusion lengths are critical considerations. The CB should be more negative than the H2 generation potential, whereas the VB should be more positive than the O2 generation potential [13,103]. 2.2.3 Surface area and crystallinity The semiconductors’ crystallinity and surface active sites are very important for e−/h+ transfer and OER/HER reactions, respectively [102]. Materials with high crystallinity and few defects can mitigate the e−/h+ recombination [104]. The rate of OER/HER reactions should be larger than backward reaction, which is mainly depending on the number of active sites [52]. Shi et al. demonstrated that the crystallinity of BiVO4 film was improved by high-temperature annealing (540 °C), which alleviated the e−/h+ recombination and enhanced PEC-WS under light irradiation [105]. Similarly, Iqba et al. [106] and Kim et al. [107] found that increasing the crystallinity of the prepared photoanodes directly boosted the PEC-WS efficiency. 2.2.4 Cost and stability of materials Photoelectrodes must be made up of readily available and cheap components that can provide for long-term PEC performance in the presence of produced gases [26]. It is preferable to use electrodes composed of earth abundant materials. The applied semiconductor photoelectrodes should be stable in acidic or basic electrolytes. Occasionally, a protective coating layer that can transmit the light is required to extend the lifetime of photoelectrodes [102]. Sun et al. deposited a homogenous layer of super hydrophilic CoFe-phytic acid complex over BiVO4 photoanode. This deposited complex served as an effective cocatalyst which boosted the kinetics of water oxidation and considerably alleviated the photo-corrosion by avoiding the direct contact between BiVO4 and electrolyte [108]. Under irradiation, the generated current density as a function of time can monitor material stability; for example, Au/CdSe nanodumbbell photoanode demonstrated stable photocurrent (1.3 mA/cm2) at 0.4 V vs. RHE for 5 days because of the high structure stability [109]. 3 Metal chalcogenide-based photoelectrode 3.1 Metal chalcogenide’s role in tuning the optical bandgap of hydride heterostructure MCs have piqued great interest in several fields because of their distinctive optical properties. The bandgap energy of MCs varies between 0.3 and 3.8 eV, depending on the material composition, as indicated in Fig. 4 [101,110]. The bandgap energy increases by decreasing the physical material size within a specific range in nanocrystalline structure [110]. The bandgap of the material determines the wavelength of absorbed light. Materials with a large bandgap can absorb a short wavelength, while materials with a small bandgap can absorb the long wavelength of irradiated light [111]. Fig. 4(d) shows the relationship between the bandgap of material and the estimated wavelength of absorbed light. The conversion among band gap energy (eV) and wavelength (nm) of irradiated light can be explained as follows [65]. h υ e V = 1239.8 ( e V x n m ) λ ( n m ) The controllable bandgap enables a variety of MCs photoelectrodes to demonstrate high activity for H2 generation [112,113]. Jiang et al. [114] reported that the absorption edge and bandgap energy of CdS were significantly affected by changing the preparation hydrothermal time owing to a change in the crystal size. The highest absorption edge of 560 nm was achieved when the hydrothermal time was 4 h (Fig. 4e). Additionally, CdS nanorods (4 h) had the lowest bandgap due to their large particle size, demonstrating the highest photocurrent density (Fig. 4f). Combining small bandgap semiconductors with wide bandgap semiconductors (WBSs) with appropriate energy band positions to generate type-II heterojunction is an effective way to maximize the energy conversion efficiency of PEC systems and improve light absorption and charge transfer performance [115–118]. The type-II (staggered) heterojunction possesses a long lifetime of charge carriers because the minimum CB and maximum VB are located at different positions of the heterojunction [119]. Recently, various TMC QDs-WBS nanocomposite photoelectrodes have been manufactured by constructing type-II band alignment that boosted the light-harvesting ability of WBS and developed e−/h+ separation [20,120–122]. Hou’s group manifested that layer-by-layer deposition of CdSe QDs on TiO2 NTAs with the aid of a polyethyleneimine thin layer formed type-II band alignment between CdSe QDs and TiO2 NTAs [20]. These deposited layers of CdSe QDs improved light absorption, red-shifted the absorption band edge, and enhanced e−/h+ separation, thereby improving the PEC performance. Lin et al. reported that the CdSe/ZnSe/ZnO NTA sandwich structure significantly increased visible light harvesting from 400 to 730 nm (1.7 eV) [123]. Altaf’s group observed that the light absorption of ZnO photoanode extended from the ultraviolet (UV) region to the visible region because of CdSe and CdS deposition (Fig. 4g). Consequently, these photoanodes demonstrated a significant increment in both efficiency and stability for PEC-WS [124]. According to Wang et al. the uniform distribution of Bi2S3 nanorods (NRs) on WO3 nanoplates constructed a type-II heterojunction, promoted e−/h+ separation and migration, and achieved excellent light absorption potential [125]. Fig. 5 (a) illustrates the significant red-shift of the bandgap due to the deposition of Bi2S3 to 1.35 eV. Mollavali et al. fabricated C, N-co-doped -TiO2 NTAs using an anodization technique and then grew NiS, CdS, and ZnS NPs on its surface using the SILAR process to improve PEC-WS performance [115]. The modification of C, N-TiO2 NTAs with different MC NPs enhanced light harvesting to the visible light range of 400–700 nm, as shown in Fig. 5(b). The bandgap decreased with the rising quantity of deposited MC NPs, as indicated in Fig. 5(c). C, N-TiO2/NiS/CdS/ZnS exhibited the lowest bandgap of 1.82 eV compared with N-TiO2/NiS and C, N-TiO2/NiS/CdS, with 2.07 and 1.97 eV, respectively. This improved the capability of C, N-TiO2/NiS/CdS/ZnS to harvest visible light, and high e−/h+ mobility improved its PEC-WS performance and displayed a superior photocurrent density of 18.79 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Wu et al. reported that Fe doping into Zn0.2Cd0.8S and a formation heterojunction with CuSbS2 extended light harvesting and improved the PEC performance of Fe-Zn0.2Cd0.8S/CuSbS2/Co-Pi composite [126]. Because of the strong synergistic effect of doped Fe and the heterojunction with CuSbS2, the Zn0.2Cd0.8S/CuSbS2/Co-Pi bandgap was 2.44 eV. Furthermore, the loaded Co-Pi accelerated the separation and transfer of e−/h+, improving PEC efficiency with exceptional stability. D. Rani et al. illustrated that the formation of a heterojunction between CdSe QDs and BaTiO3 extended light absorption to 550 nm with a rapid decrease in the bandgap to 2.25 eV, which confirmed strong visible light absorption and thus improved PEC-WS performance [127]. Andrea’s group modified TiO2 with different cadmium chalcogenides QDs (CdS, CdTe, and CdSe) to enhance its light absorption [128]. CdSe QDs/TiO2 achieved the highest light absorption capability (300–650 nm) compared with other single-modified photoanodes. Conversely, sensitized photoanodes with CdS-CdSe QDs or CdS-CdTe QDs had a broader range of light absorption with appropriate energy levels, improving charge separation/transfer and enhancing PEC activity. Shen’s group demonstrated the role of CdSe NPs in extending the light absorption of TiO2 NTA photoanode from the UV region to the visible region [129]. The absorption band edge of pure TiO2 NTAs was 400 nm, whereas, after modification with Au NCs, the harvesting peak was extended to 520 nm because of the Au LSPR effect. The deposition of CdSe NPs exhibited a noticeable red-shift from 400 to 700 nm (Fig. 5d). Because of the excellent synergistic effect between CdSe NPs and Au NCs decorated on the surface, TiO2-CdSe-Au photoanode showed higher visible light harvesting and bandgap decrement (2.38 eV) than TiO2-Au-CdSe (Fig. 5e). Li et al. [130] illustrated that the growth of a CdS/CdSe nanofilm as a sensitizer on ZnO NRs significantly improved the light-harvesting ability and reduced the bandgap. As shown in Fig. 5(f), ZnO NRs have an absorption edge and bandgap of ∼ 390 nm and 3.174 eV, respectively. CdS deposition (five cycles) on the ZnO NRs slightly extended light absorption to ∼ 470 nm and reduced the bandgap to 2.627 eV. Meanwhile, the further growth of CdSe to form ZnO-CdS5-CdSe NR photoanode remarkably improved light absorption to ∼ 700 nm, with the narrowest bandgap of 1.754. Therefore, The ZnO/CdS5/CdSe photoanode exhibited excellent photocurrent (Fig. 5g) and incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) (Fig. 5h) compared with its counterparts. 3.2 Metal mono-chalcogenide-based photoelectrodes CdTe/CdS or CdSe/CdS sensitization can improve photoconversion performance by constructing type-II band alignment and more e−/h+ photogeneration [131–133]. The doping of CdS NPs into semiconductor photocatalysts increased photoresponse by constructing a heterojunction, facilitating e−/h+ separation in the composites [134–136]. Kuang et al. synthesized wide spectral responsive Fe2O3/CdS/Co-Pi NR photoanode, as depicted in Fig. 6 (a). The deposited layers of CdS and Co-Pi reduced the reaction kinetics of Fe2O3, inhibited the charge carrier reunion, and thus improved photocurrent density at lower onset potential [137]. Chong et al. used an electrochemical deposition technique to prepare Cu2Se/CdSe/TiO2 cascade structure nanocomposite, demonstrating a photocurrent density of 28 mA/cm2, which is 14 times more than pristine TiO2 NTAs. This high efficiency was ascribed to the successful contact between Cu2Se and CdSe layers, increased light-harvesting power, and efficient e−/h+ mobility due to the cascade structure [138]. Zappia et al. reported that a GaSe nanoflake photoelectrode demonstrated the highest PEC-WS efficiency in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. It presented cathodic and anodic photocurrent − 9.3 μA/cm2 at 0 V vs. RHE and 83.4 μA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, respectively. According to their findings, a GaSe flakes photoelectrode with less than four layers can be effective for HER, whereas a photoelectrode with a minimum of four layers can be effective for OER [139]. Ruolin’s group discovered that using FeSnOS as a co-catalyst for a BiVO4 photoanode increased OER and decreased e−/h+ transfer resistance. Furthermore, a type-II heterojunction improved the bulk charge separation and significantly increased photocurrent density [140]. PEC-WS using QDs as sensitizers is a promising technique for H2 production because of QDs’ size-adjustable optical features [141,142]. QDs have significant absorption coefficients in the visible light region [143]. QDs with a narrow bandgap can be linked either physically or chemically on the surface of WBS to construct efficient photoelectrodes [144–147]. For example, CdSe QDs showed high efficiency for WS because of its suitable bandgap 1.8–3.0 eV, which matches well with solar spectra. Furthermore, it has a high light-harvesting cross-section and can make the CB of semiconductors more negative, so it can enhance redox reactions to generate H2 [148–150]. Reportedly, the heterojunction between various semiconductors and QD materials improved H2 production. For example, CdSe QDs/SrTiO3 [151], core/alloyed-shell CdSe/Pb x Cd1− x S/CdS QDs [152], CdSe QDs on BaTiO3 [153], Mn-CdS QDs/TiO2/WO3 [154], WO3/Ag/CdS NRs [155], CdS/Au/TiO2 nanotubes (NTs) [156], and PbS/Mn-doped CdS QDs/TiO2 [157]. Sheng et al. demonstrated that the deposition of metal-doped CdS QDs on three-dimensional (3D) ZnO using the SILAR method improved light absorption capability in the visible region, facilitated e−/h+ transfer, and increased PEC-WS efficiency [158]. According to the work of the Mao-Yong team, manipulating the Se-to-Cd ratio significantly impacted the efficiency of CdSe QDs photocatalysts for both PC and PEC-WS [159]. SnO2-TiO2/CdSe/CdS core–shell QD photoanodes have demonstrated a high photocurrent of approximately 4.7 mA/cm2 at 1 V vs. RHE with superior stability, maintaining 93% of the starting photocurrent density after 5 h of illumination [141]. Tekalgne et al. reported that constructing a hybrid consisting of QDs and TMDs is a promising and efficient approach for improving HER performance [160]. They used hot injection and hydrothermal processes to prepare CdSe QDs and WS2 nanoflower (NFs), respectively. The results indicated that hybrid composite 10% CdSe QDs/WS2 NFs had a higher photocurrent of −1.12 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. RHE than pure CdSe QDs and WS2 NFs. Furthermore, they discovered that the particle size (5, 10, and 50 nm) and concentration (5%, 10%, and 20%) of CdSe QDs doped in WS2 NFs played a pivotal role in HER activity. The 10 nm size and 10% concentration of CdSe QDs demonstrated the best HER performance [161]. Lai’s group explained that the loading of CdSe (less than 0.5%) on the TiO2 NTs using a CBD process served as an electron trapper, reduced e−/h+ recombination, and thus generated high photocurrent [162]. Wang et al. illustrated that the p-n junction between Cu2O NPs and CdS NRs displayed excellent PEC-WS performance, with high stability under visible light illumination. This resulted from the good synergistic effect between Cu2O NPs and CdS NRs, which assisted e−/h+ separation and mobility [163]. Ranjan’s group demonstrated that the inclusion of r GO (10 wt%) to CdS formed a heterojunction between the two materials. Consequently, there were several band bending, easy e−/h+ mobility, and a low reunion rate. Thus, GO (10 wt%)/CdS photoelectrode provided a high activity for PEC-WS [164]. The formation of a heterojunction between plasmonic metal and metal mono-chalcogenides remarkably improved visible light absorption and PEC-WS performance [122]. Wang et al. manifested that Au/CdSe nanodumbbell (Fig. 6b and c) demonstrated excellent light-harvesting ability (λ > 700 nm), with more photon absorption accompanied by enhanced H2 evolution to 45.29 µmol cm−2h−1 with STH of 2.38% [109]. Wang et al. [121] used electrochemical deposition, hydrothermal reduction, and CBD methods to fabricate ZnO/Au/CdS NTA photoanodes (Fig. 7 a–d). The presence of numerous Au NPs with a diameter of 40–50 nm was discovered via scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and the deposition of CdS NPs on ZnO/Au lowered the thickness of NTAs, resulting in ZnO/Au/CdS NTAs with a bumpy surface (Fig. 7e). The Au NPs increased the light-harvesting ability of ZnO NTAs to 525 nm because of the SPR effect [165]. Additionally, the growth of CdS demonstrated a significant red-shift to 750 nm. Compared with bare ZnO and ZnO/Au NTA, the ZnO/Au/CdS NTA photoanode displayed the highest photocurrent density of 6.5 mA/cm2 under no bias because of its outstanding light absorption and the role of Au NPs as a bridge to transmit electrons from the CB of CdS to that of ZnO. Photoelectrodes based on Cd(1− x )Zn x S have been developed to improve H2 evolution because of their appropriate band structure, morphology, surface area, crystal size, and photostability [166–170]. The N-RGO-Cd0.6Zn0.4S photoelectrode achieved a photocurrent of 0.92 mA/cm2 without applied bias potential, which was three times higher than that of the RGO-Cd0.6Zn0.4S photoelectrode. This was due to the increased e−/h+ transfer ability and the decreased e−/h+ recombination [171]. The vertically ordered ZnO NR-Zn1− x Cd x S porous nanosheet (PNS) photoanodes exhibited suitable morphology, efficient light absorption, and excellent e−/h+ separation [172]. Cao et al. fabricated TiO2 NTAs/Zn0.5Cd0.5S photoanodes using anodization and SILAR techniques. The number of cycles of Zn0.5Cd0.5S NPs significantly affected PEC-WS performance. The optimum Zn0.5Cd0.5S amount (6 cycles) deposited on TiO2 NTAs manifested the highest photocurrent of 10.95 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, and the highest IPCE of 65.0% at 390 nm [173]. This was owing to improved light harvesting and the development of type-II band alignment that improved e−/h+ separation and mobility. InSe InSe has gained a lot of interest as a photoanode for PEC-WS systems because of its good e−/h+ mobility and high efficiency in reducing their reunion rate [174]. However, it suffers from low chemical stability [175]. To increase the stability of the InSe crystal, Zheng et al. [176] encapsulated it with a monolayer of graphene (Fig. 7f). This photoanode (InSe/graphene) exhibited high photocurrent up to 10 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE with high stability. PbS PbS has a narrow bandgap of 0.37 eV [177], whereas PbS NPs can enhance light absorption in the range 1.22–3.36 eV [178,179]. Majumder et al. [117] reported that constructing the n-p heterojunction at the β-Bi2O3/PbS interface increased the current density by twice that of pure β-Bi2O3 nanoflakes. This was attributed to the significant role of PbS in improving light absorption and e−/h+ migration. Table 1 summarizes the recent progress of metal mono-chalcogenides applied for PEC-WS. 3.3 Metal di-chalcogenide-based photoelectrodes MDCs have trigonal or octahedral prismatic structures. The bonding among chalcogenide-chalcogenide layers is weak, while bonding among metal and chalcogenide ligands is strong [185]. TMDCs semiconductors are promising because of their unique physical, electronic, and optical properties [35,36,186–188]. Recently, two-dimensional (2D) graphene-like layered structures (e.g., MoS2, SnS2, and WSe2) have been considered promising candidates for low-cost, earth-abundant catalytic substances for WS [189–194]. These materials have bandgaps in the range of 1.07–2.44 eV, enabling them to absorb a wide range of solar spectra [195,196]. Table 2 . shows the recent progress of metal di-chalcogenides applied for PEC-WS. MoS2 Baoliang group observed that the intimate contact between MoS2 and In2S3 significantly facilitated e−/h+ separation, which extended their lifetime against reunion. Therefore, MoS2 and In2S3 photocathodes demonstrated excellent PEC-WS efficiency [197]. The Schottky junction formed between MoS2 and MoO2 improved HER activity by facilitating e−/h+ separation and transfer [198]. Seo et al. used the MOCVD process to construct vertically aligned layers of MoS2 flakes on TiO2 nanowires (NWs). The generated heterojunction between MoS2 flakes and TiO2 NWs facilitated e−/h+ separation and migration, increasing the photocurrent density at low onset potential [199]. Bhat’s group investigated the use of MoS2 nanosheets (NSs) to enhance the PEC activity of a TiO2/CdS photoanode [200]. MoS2 NSs acted as a hole trapper, making e−/h+ separation easier by forming a type-II heterojunction with CdS. The role of MoS2 NSs in increasing the charge carriers lifetime was also verified via photoluminescence (PL) spectra. The ternary photoanode TiO2/CdS/MoS2 displayed the highest photocurrent of 3.25 mA/cm2 at 0.9 V vs. RHE compared with pure TiO2 and TiO2/CdS photoanodes. Hassan et al. reported that the heterojunction between MoS2 and GaN increased photoresponse to visible light and that MoS2 also reduced the resistance of e−/h+ transportation at the interface between the semiconductor and electrolyte, which improved e−/h+ separation. Consequently, MoS2/GaN manifested superior PEC-WS efficiency than pristine GaN photoanode [201]. Li et al. reported that (MoS2-TiO2)/Au photoanodes showed a surge in the photocurrent density and H2 production rate with 42% and 52%, respectively, compared with MoS2-TiO2. This is due to the SPR of Au NPs and efficient charge mobility [202]. The construction of heterojunction between two materials can introduce band bending at the interface among different Fermi energy levels, facilitating e−/h+ migration in opposite directions. Sitara et al. used a sonochemical method to fabricate p-n heterojunction MoS2/CoTe with various MoS2 and CoTe ratios (1:3, 1:1, and 3:1). According to the LSV measurements, the MoS2/CoTe (1:1) composite attained a maximum photocurrent of 2.791 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which was 11 times more than MoS2. Additionally, it achieved the highest STH conversion efficiency 0.84%, whereas MoS2 and CoTe achieved 0.14%, and 0.08%, respectively. This superior PEC activity was owing to the efficient charge separation with a long lifetime and reduced e−/h+ reunion rate [203]. Kumar et al. compared the PEC-WS performance of two core–shell structures NaNbO3/BiVO4 and NaNbO3/MoS2. NaNbO3/MoS2 showed the lowest charge transfer resistance and the highest STH conversion efficiency with the maximum photocurrent of 4.54 mA/cm2 at −1.0 V compared with NaNbO3/BiVO4, NaNbO3, and MoS2. This was ascribed to the appropriate lattice match with type-II band alignment and the extension of light harvesting to the visible light range [204]. Li et al. demonstrated that MoS2 NSs/ZnO NWs binary composite had the highest photocurrent density of 0.25 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. SCE, which was greater than pure ZnO NWs and MoS2 NSs. This enhanced PEC-WS performance was attributed to proper face-to-face contact between 2D MoS2 NSs and ZnO NWs, which helped electrons move from the CB of MoS2 to that of ZnO and then to Pt CE, as well as holes transfer to the MoS2 and electrolyte interface. Additionally, the optimum deposited amount of MoS2 improved the light-harvesting ability [205]. Hu et al. fabricated a MoS2/ hydrogenated anatase/rutile TiO2 (A-H-RTNA) photocathode through a hydrothermal process. They used the 16MoS2/A-H-RTNA (prepared under the optimum hydrothermal setting 200 °C and 16 h) as a counter electrode rather than a Pt electrode in the presence of A-H-RTNA as a photoanode (Fig. 8 a). H2 generation on MoS2/A-H-RTNA and Pt CEs were 980 and 1300 mmol m−2h−1, respectively (Fig. 8b). Thus, 16MoS2/A-H-RTNA’s PEC-WS performance was 75% that of the Pt electrode [206]. SnS2 SnS2 is a TMDC with a bandgap of 2.1 eV and a large interlayer spacing that aids e−/h+ transfer [207,208]. Zhang et al. fabricated SnS2/CuInS2 NS photocathodes in which CuInS2 NSs were first deposited on the FTO substrate; then, a thin layer of SnS2 NSs was epitaxially deposited on CuInS2 NSs on both sides. The SnS2/CuInS2 NSs photocathode contained a lot of active sites and a fast e−/h+ migration channel, which improved PEC-WS and its stability significantly [209]. Liu et al. used the chemical vapor decomposition (CVD) method to fabricate 2D SnS2 NSs vertically ordered on FTO and carbon cloth substrates; 2D SnS2 NSs deposited on carbon cloth photoanodes displayed the highest photocurrent and IPCE, with the values of 1.92 mA/cm2 at 1.4 V vs. RHE and 40.57% at 360 nm, respectively. Meanwhile, 2D SnS2 NSs decorated on FTO photoanodes demonstrated 1.73 mA/cm2 and 36.76% [192]. Li et al. used a two-step hydrothermal technique to fabricate an α-Fe2O3 NRs/SnS2 NSs core/shell photoanode (Fig. 8c and d). This photoanode exhibited higher PEC efficiency than pure α-Fe2O3 NRs because of the excellent e−/h+ separation and more active sites. Additionally, further decoration with Cu2O NPs to form an α-Fe2O3/SnS2/Cu2O photoanode significantly increased the current density (Fig. 8e) [210]. Xu et al. fabricated Cu2O/g-C3N4/WS2 ternary composite photocathode using a layer-by-layer technique. This photocathode had multifaceted merits; Cu2O worked as a light-harvesting active layer, whereas g-C3N4 formed a p-n heterojunction with Cu2O and protected it, and WS2 served as a powerful HER catalyst. Hence, this photocathode generated a high photocurrent of − 9.5 mA/cm2 at − 0.55 V vs. RHE under visible light [211]. Li et al. fabricated a hybrid of 3D TiO2 NFs/2D MoSe2 NSs, and it showed a considerable increase in the PEC-WS activity compared with bare TiO2 NFs and MoSe2 NSs. The results elucidated that TiO2 NFs/MoSe2-15 demonstrated the greatest photocurrent density of 1.40 mA/cm2 because of the boosted light-harvesting efficiency and efficient e−/h+ separation and migration after MoSe2 incorporation [212]. Huang et al. deposited a 2D layer of ReS2 on a p-type Si photocathode to fabricate a ReS2/Si photocathode. They used the argon ion beam bombardment technique to introduce atomic vacancy defects on ReS2 NSs. The ReS2/Si-30 photocathode displayed the highest photocurrent of − 18.5 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. RHE. The well-defined and abundant atomic Re vacancies generated on ReS2 NSs, and excellent charge mobility are responsible for this enhanced activity [213]. Kim et al. incorporated p-CuInSe2 NPs into n-CuIn3Se5 to form 3D n-CuIn3Se5/p-CuInSe2 photoanode [214]. This p-n heterojunction, which was covered with a thin protective layer of Al2O3, achieved high stability and photocurrent of 12.7 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE. Bozheyev et al. observed that the homogenous distribution of semiconductors on WSe2 van der Waals crystals is an excellent way to improve H2 production using a photocathode with a large area. The heterojunction formed in (NH4)2Mo3S13/WSe2 composite achieved a high photocurrent 5.6 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. RHE [215]. The Au (111 plane) incorporation into the 2D FeS2 pyrite structure generated Au–FeS2 heterojunction photocathode with high PEC-WS efficiency, producing 10 mA/cm2 at 0.08 V vs. RHE [216]. 3.4 Metal tri-chalcogenides based photoelectrodes Bi2S3 Bismuth sulfide (Bi2S3) has a high absorption coefficient (104–105) and a direct bandgap of 1.3 eV, making it suitable for a variety of photocatalytic applications [125,219,220]. Sadhasivam et al. found that Bi2S3 NSs increased photoresponse to the visible field, reduced e−/h+ recombination, and facilitated their migration, accompanied by high PEC-WS activity of Bi2S3/ZnS/ZnO photoanode [221]. Geng et al. clarified that the V-rich Bi2S3 NW photoanode demonstrated high visible light absorption, efficient e−/h+ separation, and charge transfer, as well as superior PEC activity and stability [222]. Huang et al. supported Bi2S3 NRs on TiO2 nanoplates (001 facet) to generate the Bi2S3/(001) TiO2 heterojunction. This binary nanocomposite showed the highest photocurrent of 2.035 mA/cm2 at 0.9 V vs. Ag/AgCl compared with pristine TiO2 and Bi2S3. The results indicated that TiO2 nanoplates with the 001 facet could be combined with Bi2S3 to increase PEC-WS activity. The excellent charge separation through electron migration from the CB of Bi2S3 to that of TiO2 and hole shift from the VB of TiO2 to that of Bi2S3 were observed [223]. Ahmad et al. fabricated a 3D rosette-rod TiO2/Bi2S3 photoanode on an FTO substrate using hydrothermal, SILAR, and solvothermal methods. The suitable amount and homogenous distribution of Bi2S3 on TiO2, broad light absorption, appropriate bandgap positions, and enhanced e−/h+ separation were responsible for the high PEC activity and stability of the rosette-rod TiO2/Bi2S3 photoanode [224]. The 3D hierarchical PANI/Bi2S3 NF photoanode exhibited significantly improved PEC-WS efficiency than pure Bi2S3 NFs [225]. Xiong et al. demonstrated that the vdW interaction between In2S3 NSs and Bi2S3 NRs decreased the electron’s transfer time, increased the photovoltage, and substantially increased the photocurrent [226]. The use of Zr-doped Fe2O3, along with another appropriate bandgap semiconductor, has been proposed as a simple way to improve e−/h+ separation. Mahadik’s group fabricated Bi2S3 NSs/Ag interlayer/Zr:Fe2O3 NR photoanode using a hydrothermal technique [227]. This unique heterojunction structure achieved a high photocurrent of 1.27 mA/cm2. This was attributed to the suitable morphology and energy levels in Bi2S3 NSs/Zr:Fe2O3 NRs, which improved light absorption and e−/h+ separation. The excited electron drift from the CB of Bi2S3 NS to that of Zr:Fe2O3 NRs, then to the CE to undergo a reduction reaction. Instantaneously, positive holes move from the VB of Zr:Fe2O3 NR to Bi2S3 NSs, which consequently reduces the reunion rate (Fig. 9 a and b). Furthermore, the inclusion of an Ag interlayer enhanced stability and facilitated electron transfer from Bi2S3 NSs to Zr:Fe2O3 /FTO due to the SPR effect, thereby reducing the charge reunion (Fig. 9c and d). The fabrication of plasmonic metal NPs-metal chalcogenide semiconductor heterojunction has received considerable attention to achieve the best PEC efficiency [228]. The plasmonic metal NPs inhibit e−/h+ recombination and demonstrate a substantial improvement of the photoresponse achieved by the SPR effect [86,229,230]. Au NPs/Bi2S3 NRs manifested superior photocurrent to 9.61 mA/cm2 at 1.23 vs. RHE, with STH of 5.78%, respectively, which was three times than pure Bi2S3 photoanode. This was ascribed to the appropriate optical/electronic characteristics [231]. Subramanyam et al. reported that the inclusion of Cu NPs into WO3/Bi2S3 photoanode facilitated electron migration from the CB of Bi2S3 to that of WO3 CB. Furthermore, the Bi2S3 significantly increased light absorption. Consequently, WO3/Cu/Bi2S3 photoanode showed the highest photocurrent to 10.6 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE compared with its bare counterparts [232]. Sharma’s group incorporated Ag NPs into Bi2S3 NRs (Fig. 10 a) and Bi2S3 NFs (Fig. 10b) using a chemical route [233]. The photocurrent density was improved after grafting Ag NPs into Bi2S3 due to the developed photoresponse, a rapid drift of hot electrons from the CB of Ag NPs to that of Bi2S3, and efficient charge separation (Fig. 10c and d). The Ag NPs/Bi2S3 NF photoanode demonstrated appreciable improved PEC performance compared with Ag NPs/Bi2S3 NR photoanode due to its larger surface area and numerous active sites. The g-C3N4/Bi2S3/Bi NP photoanode had the highest photocurrent value of 7.11 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which was 10 and 5 times greater than the g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/Bi2S3 photoanodes, respectively. This significant enhancement in PEC performance was due to the SPR effect of Bi NPs, increase light-harvesting, and charge density. Additionally, Bi2S3 QDs created a light absorption field and inhibited e−/h+ recombination [234]. Li et al. loaded Au NPs on Cu3BiS3 NFs to improve the PEC-WS operation. Au/Cu3BiS3 NFs had a higher photocurrent density and substantially increased PEC activity than pure Cu3BiS3 NFs. Au NPs acted as electron capture, which improved e−/h+ separation and increased light absorption due to the SPR effect [235]. Sb2Se3 Recently, Sb2Se3 has attracted significant attention as an excellent light-harvesting substance for solar energy conversion [113,236]. This is due to its small bandgap (1–1.3 eV), high harvesting coefficient, and h+ mobility [237]. The Sb2Se3 photocathode displayed a good photocurrent of approximately 30 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. RHE [238]. Yang et al. modulated the anisotropy of one-dimensional (1D) Sb2Se3 nanomaterials by adjusting the thioglycolic acid (TGA) and ethanolamine ratio. They deposited TiO2 and Pt on Sb2Se3 to form the Pt/TiO2/Sb2Se3 (TGA 5) photocathode, which showed the highest photocurrent. The creation of a properly aligned nanostructure, which facilitated e−/h+ migration and increased light absorption ability, was responsible for this significant efficiency [63]. Another study focused on tuning the anisotropic structure of 1D Sb2Se3 NRs and sputtered a layer of MoS2 to serve as a co-catalyst and a protective coating on Sb2Se3 NRs. This prepared core–shell MoS2/Sb2Se3 NR photocathode achieved a photocurrent density of −10 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. RHE in a pH 6.5 solution. This improved activity was ascribed to the enhanced e−/h+ mobility and light-harvesting capacity by quasi-1D ribbons (Sb4Se6)m formed on the Sb2Se3 surface. Additionally, the MoS2 protective thin layer prevented the photo-corrosion of Sb2Se3 NRs, accelerated by the charge carrier mobility, and catalyzed H+ reduction to H2 [239]. Sb2S3 Sb2S3 has received huge attention as an excellent light-harvesting substance because of its ideal bandgap (1.7–1.9 eV), high optical harvesting coefficient (1.8 × 105 cm−1), and eco-friendly characteristics [240–242]. Bi NPs and Sb2S3 on TiO2 resulted in a highly efficient and stable ternary photoanode. This was due to the SPR effect of Bi NPs, that increased electron drift from the CB of Sb2S3 to that of TiO2 [217]. The deposition of Sb2S3 on 5% Mo-WO3 composite significantly increased visible light absorption and decreased the bandgap to 1.8 eV. Furthermore, it inhibited the gathering of h+ at the interface between the Sb2S3/5% Mo-WO3 photoanode and electrolyte. Consequently, the Sb2S3/5% Mo-WO3 photoanode had a higher photocurrent of 0.42 mA/cm2 than its constituents [243]. Chen et al. used a hydrothermal process to incorporate Sb2S3 and Co-Pi into α-Fe2O3 with NP and NR morphologies to alleviate e−/h+ recombination. The α-Fe2O3 NRs/Sb2S3/Co-Pi photoanode exhibited the excellent photocurrent of 1.14 mA/cm2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE and with the lowest onset potential. This significant improvement was ascribed to the improved charge separation and migration and extended light harvesting to the visible field, which was caused by modification using Sb2S3 and Co-Pi [244]. Cheng et al. reported that the optimized sulfurization of Sb2Se3/FTO assisted the Sb2S3 growth within Sb2Se3 nanorods and led to the formation of Sb2(S x Se1− x )3 nanorods. The prepared Sb2(S x Se1− x )3 photocathode demonstrated a higher photocurrent of 30 folds than pure Sb2Se3 photocathode. The cascaded band alignment of Sb2(S x Se1− x )3 facilitated charge separation and transfer [245]. In2S3 In2S3 has piqued the interest of many researchers because of its photosensitivity [246], high conductivity [247], and chemical stability [248]. Xiong et al. [249] prepared a size-controlled P-In2S3 NS photoanode using the preceding technique (Fig. 11 a). These doped P impurities tuned the electronic structure of In2S3, suppressed the e−/h+ reunion rate, and improved the surface reaction kinetics. Consequently, the homogenous P-In2S3 NSs deposited on the FTO substrate (Fig. 11b) demonstrated a remarkable increase in photocurrent because of the synergistic effect between the size and doped P impurities. Tian et al. deposited In2S3 NSs on a WO3 nanowall and then treated them with polyvinylpyrrolidone to create oxygen and sulfur vacancies in the In2S3 NSs that resulted in type-II band alignment at the WO3/In2S3 interface. Additionally, it facilitated e−/h+ separation and migration, prolonged their lifetime, and thus enhanced PEC-WS activity [250]. Wang et al. illustrated that constructing a direct Z-scheme heterojunction between ReS2 and In2S3 with the generation of a trap-like feature increased the light absorption range, e−/h+ separation, and migration, thereby improving PEC efficiency [251]. Table 3 introduces the recent progress of metal tri-chalcogenide-based photoelectrodes applied for PEC-WS. 3.5 Drawbacks of metal chalcogenide-based photoelectrodes MCs alone have low photocatalytic activity under light irradiation due to the high reunion rate of e−/h+ and photo-corrosion, resulting in low energy conversion efficiency [253,254]. Three approaches were applied to improve the e−/h+ separation and inhibit the photo-corrosion process [255,256]. (1) The utilization of electrolyte containing sacrificial reagent that can capture the extra holes which cause the photo-corrosion process [137,224,257]. For example, Na2SO3 and Na2S serves as a sacrificial reagent and capture the extra holes and oxidized sulfides ( S 2 - ); to disulfides ( S 2 2 - ), therefore it inhibits the corrosion of Bi2S3. Moreover, Na2SO3 reduces S 2 2 - to S 2 - , S 2 2 - + S O 3 2 - → S 2 - + S 2 O 3 2 - which resulted in a considerable increase of H2 quantity at the counter electrode [231,258,259]. (2) The loading of noble metal [260–265], or non-noble metals on the semiconductors [266–271]. These metals work as co-catalysts that enhance the OER by reducing the water oxidation overpotential and thereby rapidly consume the holes present on the semiconductor surface [272]. (3) The use of a protective coating on the photoactive surface [273–277]. This protective layer should be chemically inert, have high conductivity, and be exceedingly uniform. For instance, a passivation layer of ZnS can protect CdS NPs from photo-corrosion [115,153,278]. The shell material in the core/shell heterojunction mitigates the surface ions dissociation in the core [16,95,181,279–281]. Sheng et al. used a hydrothermal method to wrap CdS NRs with vertically ordered MoS2/In2S3 NSs constructing CdS NR as a core and MoS2/In2S3 as a shell [181]. The prepared CdS@MoS2/In2S3 heterostructure exhibited the lowest PL intensity, which confirmed the efficient e−/h+ separation. It also showed the highest photocurrent of approximately 2 mA/cm2 at 0.14 V vs. RHE compared with pure CdS NRs, CdS@In2S3, and CdS@MoS2 nanocomposite. 4 Charge transfer at MC/semiconductor interface PEC-WS starts with the light absorption process; hence, the energy and quantity of photons are key constraints. First, when a semiconductor absorbs photons, electrons in the VB can excite to the CB generating holes in the VB. This process of e−/h+ generation is the primary process, and the amount of charge in the process is based on the number of absorbed photons. Sometimes, e−/h+ promptly recombines and emits the corresponding energy, which is unfavorable for the PEC-WS process. Thus, the second necessary process is e−/h+ separation and migration [282]. In an n-type photoanode, the top of the VB should be more positive than the O2 generation potential, and holes in the VB migrate to the electrolyte to oxidize H2O to O2. Meanwhile, in a p-type photocathode, the CB edge should be more negative than the H2 generation potential, and electrons migrate to the electrolyte to drive the reduction of protons to H2. Tandem cells contain photoanode and photocathode at the same time [98,238]. 4.1 n-type photoanode Subramanyam et al. [231] proposed the mechanism of e−/h+ transfer and PEC-WS over Au NPs/Bi2S3NR photoanode. As Bi2S3 was exposed to solar light, electrons were excited to the CB, leaving positive holes in the VB. The band positions in Bi2S3 corresponded to water reduction and oxidation potentials. Furthermore, the Fermi level of Au NPs was lower than that of Bi2S3 CB. Therefore, the excited electrons drifted from the CB of Bi2S3 to Au NPs. Then, these hot electrons were reintroduced into the CB of Bi2S3 and finally to FTO [233,283,284]. Through the external circuit, these electrons traveled to the Pt electrode and reduced H+ to H2. Simultaneously, positive holes formed in the VB of Bi2S3 reacted with S2− and SO3 2− ions in the electrolyte, preventing corrosion of the Bi2S3 photoanode. Thus, the excellent synergistic effect in Au NPs/Bi2S3NR photoanode was responsible for the superior photoresponse and facilitated e−/h+ separation and migration, increasing PEC efficiency for H2 production. Lin et al. illustrated e−/h+ transfer and PEC-WS mechanisms using a CdSe/ZnSe/ZnO NTA sandwich photoanode [123]. The PEC efficiency of ZnSe/ZnO NTA photoanode demonstrated a slight increase compared with pure ZnO. This is due to the construction of a type-II band alignment [285,286], which made the CB of ZnSe more negative than that of ZnO. Thus, the excited electrons in the CB of ZnSe migrated to the CB of ZnO and, finally, transferred to the Pt electrode to reduce H+ and produce H2. Simultaneously, holes in the VB of ZnO migrated to the VB of ZnSe and then reacted with the scavenger electrolyte, resulting in highly efficient e−/h+ separation (Fig. 12 a). In the CdSe/ZnSe/ZnO NTA sandwich photoanode, electrons in the CB of both ZnSe and CdSe are transferred to the CB of ZnO and then to the Pt CE. Instantaneously, the holes in the VB of ZnO and ZnSe moved to the VB of CdSe and finally reacted with the scavenger electrolyte (Fig. 12b and c). Consequently, the CdSe/ZnSe/ZnO NTA sandwich photoanode remarkably improved PEC-WS to generate H2. Patil et al. [172] demonstrated the charge production and separation mechanism of ZnO NR-Zn1− x Cd x S PNS photoanode (Fig. 13 a and b). The photogenerated electrons in the ZnO NR-Zn1− x Cd x S PNS photoanode could drift through two paths: a) electrons in both CB of Zn1− x Cd x S PNS and ZnO NR simply migrated to the Zn foil, and b) the drift of electrons from the CB of Zn1− x Cd x S PNS to the CB of ZnO NRs due to the electric field generated at the ZnO NR-Zn1− x Cd x S PNS interface. These collected electrons on the Zn foil migrated to the Pt electrode to reduce H+, whereas holes in the VB of the ZnO NR and porous Zn1− x Cd x S NSs were transferred to the photoanode surface, where they reacted with the scavenger electrolyte. Besides enhancing visible light absorption, the ZnO NR/Zn1− x Cd x S PNS photoanode improved e−/h+ separation, resulting in a higher photocurrent density. Reactions that occurred in PEC-WS over the ZnO NR-Zn1− x Cd x S PNS photoanode were as follows [287]. Sharma et al. [225] illustrated the improved PEC-WS process over 3D PANI/Bi2S3 NF photoanode (Fig. 14 ). The LUMO (−1.9 eV vs. NHE) and HOMO (+0.8 eV vs. NHE) energy levels of PANI [288] are more negative than the CB (−0.14 eV vs. NHE) and VB (+1.26 eV vs. NHE) of Bi2S3 [233]. When the PANI/Bi2S3 NF photoanode was exposed to visible light, e−/ h+ were photogenerated in PANI and Bi2S3. The photoexcited electrons migrated from the LUMO of PANI to the CB of Bi2S3; simultaneously, the photogenerated holes drifted from the VB of Bi2S3 to the HOMO of PANI. Consequently, efficient e−/h+ separation in opposite directions was beneficial for improving PEC-WS efficiency. Holes on the HOMO of PANI could not produce oxygen because HOMO level was less positive (+0.8 eV vs. NHE) than the required oxidation potential of water (1.23 eV vs. NHE) [289]. Thus, the holes in Bi2S3 VB were responsible for water oxidation because it was more positive than the required oxidation potential of water. The electrons in the CB of Bi2S3 were consumed in two paths. (i) They could react with oxygen and hydrogen ions to produce hydrogen peroxide. (ii) They could directly drift to the Pt electrode through the external circuit to reduce H+. Meanwhile, the holes in the HOMO level of PANI are transferred to the electrolyte and reacted with the sulfate ions. Therefore, developed PEC-WS efficiency of the PANI/ Bi2S3 photoanode was due to the improved light harvesting and excellent e−/h+ separation caused by the formed type-II heterojunction. 4.2 p-type photocathode Li et al. [36] demonstrated the charge carrier transfer and PEC-WS mechanism using Cu(In,Ga)S2 photocathode (Fig. 15 ). Under light irradiation, electrons in Cu(In,Ga)S2 excited to the CB while creating holes in the VB. The externally applied bias assisted electron transfer from the CB of Cu(In,Ga)S2 to the electrolyte for H2 generation. Simultaneously, holes in the VB of Cu(In,Ga)S2 migrated to the Pt electrode to produce O2. Zhang et al. [209] explained the e−/h+ transfer and PEC-WS mechanism over a C60-decorated SnS2/CuInS2 NS photocathode (Fig. 16 ). When the photocathode was exposed to visible light, e−/h+ was generated in SnS2 and CuInS2. Conversely, C60 worked as a sensitizer to harvest visible light. The CB of CuInS2 was higher than that of SnS2, so electrons migrated from the CB of CuInS2 to that of SnS2 and finally to C60 to absorb and reduce H+. Meanwhile, holes in the VB of SnS2 migrated to that of CuInS2 because of the difference in energy levels. This excellent e−/h+ separation and the vital role of C60 in increasing the light absorption and protecting SnS2/CuInS2 from oxidation greatly enhanced PEC-WS efficiency. Zhang et al. [218] demonstrated the mechanism of charge transfer and PEC-HER over an n+p-Si/Ti/Ru-MoS2 photocathode (Fig. 17 ). When the photocathode was exposed to visible light, the excited electrons drifted from the VB to the CB generating holes in the VB. Then, the electric field in n+p-Si separated these photogenerated charges. The layer of Ti and TiO x on the Si improved the photoelectrode conductivity and preserved the silicon surface by forcing h+ to migrate to the photoanode through the external circuit [290]. The Ru-MoS2 heterostructure increased band bending and decreased electron transfer resistance at the interface, facilitating e−/h+ separation and mobility. Therefore, electrons drifted rapidly to the photocathode-liquid interface to react with H+ and generate hydrogen. 5 Conclusions and future perspectives The PEC-WS cell can convert H2O and sunlight directly into H2 and O2. The fundamental processes involved in PEC-WS are (1) light absorption and charge photogeneration, (2) charge separation and transfer, and (3) water splitting redox reactions. In all solar conversion systems, the semiconductor material is the most important component, which absorbs photon energy and generates excited electrons (e−) and holes (h+). This photogenerated e−/h+ can migrate in opposite directions with the formation of photopotential, which drives the production of fuel such as H2. Therefore, the fabrication of cost-effective, highly stable, and efficient photoelectrodes that can be used for sustainable energy production is necessary. Heterostructure photoelectrodes exhibit better efficiency than their counterparts because they modify band bending at the interface and result in e−/h+ separation, thereby alleviating the charge reunion and back reaction. Ideally, efficient photoelectrodes for PEC-WS should have high crystallinity and a bandgap in the range of 1.6–2.4 eV. The CB should be more negative than the H2 generation potential, whereas VB should be more positive than the O2 generation potential. Furthermore, it must be made up of readily available and cheap components that can achieve long-term PEC performance in the presence of the produced gases. Recently, varied types of MC-based photoelectrodes with various morphologies and chemical compositions (including QDs, NSs, NPs, NRs, composites, and thin films) have been studied for PEC-WS owing to their exceptional light-harvesting capacity and unique energy levels. The low energy conversion efficiency of pure MCs was attributed to the high reunion rate of e−/h+ and photo-corrosion. To overcome these problems, three approaches were applied; (1) the utilization of electrolyte-containing sacrificial reagent that can capture the extra holes which cause the photo-corrosion process, (2) the loading of noble or/and non-noble metals on the semiconductors. (3) the use of a protective coating on the photoactive surface. The heterojunction construction between MCs and broad bandgap semiconductors with appropriate energy band positions generates type-II heterojunction, facilitates charge separation and mobility, and enhances the light absorption ability. Although significant progress has been achieved using various metal (mono-, di-, and tri-) chalcogenide/semiconductor photoelectrodes, several challenges are still present for the use of MCs as photoelectrodes; • PEC-WS efficiency is typically affected by the structure, morphology, and particle size of the photoelectrode materials. Thus, tremendous attention should be paid to the composition, anisotropic features, and the specific surface area of MC/semiconductor photoelectrodes. • MCs with a small particle size have demonstrated great merits because of their many active sites and high conductivity, but unfortunately, they can aggregate easily and display low stability. Thus, it is urgent to develop precise techniques for fabricating MCs with unique electronic structures, pure phase, high active interface, and good heterojunction with other materials to improve their PEC-WS efficiency and stability. • Controlling charge separation and mobility to specific active sites, as well as investigating the practical application of MC/semiconductor photoelectrodes, is a significant challenge. Despite the challenges mentioned above present in MC/semiconductor photoelectrodes, massive progress has been made in the development of MCs. coredata.dc:description: Photoelectrochemical water splitting (PEC-WS) is a promising technique for transforming solar energy into storable and environmentally friendly chemical energy. Designing semiconductor photoelectrodes with high light absorption capability, rapid e−/h+ separation and transfer, and sufficient chemical stability is vital for developing an efficient PEC-WS system. Metal chalcogenides (MCs) have emerged as promising candidates for light absorbers because of their unique electrical and optical characteristics. In this review, we present recent developments in hydrogen generation via PEC-WS using MC-based photoelectrodes. First, we present a simple illustration of PEC-WS fundamentals. Second, the current performance of various metal (mono-, di-, and tri-) chalcogenide/semiconductor photoelectrodes in PEC-WS is summarized. Then, the charge transfer mechanism at the MC/semiconductor interface and the PEC-WS mechanism is thoroughly explained. Finally, we discuss future research perspectives toward developing efficient and stable MC/semiconductor photoelectrodes.
